messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

The test `['org.joda.time.TestMonthDay_Basics.testPlusMonths_int_negativeFromLeap()']` failed.
The test looks like:

```java
458 :     public void testPlusMonths_int_negativeFromLeap() {
459 :         MonthDay test = new MonthDay(2, 29, ISOChronology.getInstanceUTC());
460 :         MonthDay result = test.plusMonths(-1); // error occurred here
463 :     }
```

It failed with the following error message and call stack:

```
org.joda.time.IllegalFieldValueException: Value 29 for dayOfMonth must be in the range [1,28]
	at org.joda.time.field.FieldUtils.verifyValueBounds(FieldUtils.java:218)
	at org.joda.time.field.PreciseDurationDateTimeField.set(PreciseDurationDateTimeField.java:78)
	at org.joda.time.chrono.BasicMonthOfYearDateTimeField.add(BasicMonthOfYearDateTimeField.java:213)
	at org.joda.time.MonthDay.withFieldAdded(MonthDay.java:519)
	at org.joda.time.MonthDay.plusMonths(MonthDay.java:592)
	at org.joda.time.TestMonthDay_Basics.testPlusMonths_int_negativeFromLeap(TestMonthDay_Basics.java:460)
ISO_UTC = ISOChronology[UTC]
BUDDHIST_UTC = BuddhistChronology[UTC]
COPTIC_TOKYO = CopticChronology[Asia/Tokyo]
zone = America/Los_Angeles
PARIS = Europe/Paris
COPTIC_PARIS = CopticChronology[Europe/Paris]
test = --02-29
LONDON = Europe/London
TOKYO = Asia/Tokyo
COPTIC_UTC = CopticChronology[UTC]
BUDDHIST_TOKYO = BuddhistChronology[Asia/Tokyo]
TEST_TIME_NOW = 13737600000
```

Start by calling the `get_failing_tests_covered_classes` function.

The failing test `org.joda.time.TestMonthDay_Basics.testPlusMonths_int_negativeFromLeap()` belongs to the `org.joda.time` package, which covers classes such as `IllegalFieldValueException`, `MonthDay`, `DateTimeUtils`, `DateTimeFieldType`, `DateTime`, and more.

I am unable to retrieve the methods covered by the failing test `org.joda.time.TestMonthDay_Basics.testPlusMonths_int_negativeFromLeap()` directly. Let me retrieve the code snippet for the method `testPlusMonths_int_negativeFromLeap` to analyze it further.

messages.name: get_code_snippet

messages.content:
The failing test method `testPlusMonths_int_negativeFromLeap()` is attempting to create a `MonthDay` instance with the date February 29th, which is an invalid date for that year. This results in an `IllegalFieldValueException` when trying to operate on this instance by subtracting a month. The error message indicates that the day of the month must be in the range [1, 28], causing the failure in this scenario.

Do you want me to identify the methods that need to be fixed?

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
